awd_titl_txt: Variability in the Rate and Pattern of Global Warming: Forced and Unforced Components
awd_abstract_narration:
The observed increase in global temperature has varied in time, with periods of enhanced or reduced warming (such as the so-called "global warming hiatus" between 1998 and 2013) and in space, with regions that warm more or less than the global mean. The goal of this work is to understand the different processes contributing to this variability in the rate and pattern of global warming. Determining the relative importance of greenhouse gasses, anthropogenic aerosols, and internal atmospheric and oceanic variability for observed temperature changes is critical to constrain the climate response to further greenhouse gas emissions over the 21st century. This research helps bridge the gap between our scientific understanding of global climate change and the practical need to understand how it manifests in a particular place and at a particular time. The statistical methods to be developed and tested under this project will provide a valuable new resource for monitoring climate variability and change, and the associated code will be shared publicly. This project involves the support and mentoring of a postdoctoral researcher, thus helping to train the next generation of climate scientists. The results of this project will be disseminated widely through publications, conference presentations, press releases, and outreach to the public.

This project aims to identify spatial patterns of surface temperature anomalies (or fingerprints) that are associated with particular mechanisms of climate variability and external forcings (e.g., due to greenhouse gasses or anthropogenic aerosols) by using statistical analysis of both climate model output and observations. The skill of these methods in separating forced climate responses from natural climate variability will be tested within large ensembles of climate model simulations where each simulation has a unique realization of internal variability. These methods will then be applied to give a new best estimate of the anthropogenic influence on surface temperature changes in observations. These fingerprints help disentangle and understand influences on climate from external forcings and internal variability such that the evolution of climate signals associated with external forcings can be tracked. The findings of this project will contribute new insights on the mechanisms of temperature variability in the tropical Pacific and Southern Ocean and on the role of the ocean in moderating the global climate response to anthropogenic perturbations. The temperature fingerprints identified in the work will help to understand where ocean observations can lead to the largest improvements in model-based multi-year forecasts of climate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Global temperatures are rising due to anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions, but the rate of warming varies in both space and time. This project investigated the processes contributing to the spatial and temporal variation in warming rate and developed methods to quantify the anthropogenic influence on regional climate change.

The primary reason for temporal departures from the average global warming rate is natural climate variability. For example, natural variability of the atmosphere and ocean lead to a slowdown in the rate of global warming between 1998 and 2013, in what has been referred to as the ?global warming hiatus?. Building on our past work, which developed methods for objectively identifying different types of internal variability (referred to as modes of variability), this project advanced our understanding of how different modes of variability influence Earth?s energy imbalance and the rate of global warming. A major finding is that slow modes of variability in the high latitude oceans can cause long-lived anomalies in global temperature without a large influence on Earth?s energy imbalance, while modes of variability in the tropical oceans cause large anomalies in Earth?s energy imbalance with smaller impacts on global temperature. This work also advanced understanding of the processes causing this variability in global temperature and Earth?s energy imbalance. The Earth?s energy imbalance is fundamental to estimating how much the globe will warm in response to a doubling of CO2 (referred to as climate sensitivity), and this internal variability therefore leads to uncertainty in estimates of climate sensitivity from the historical record. This project quantified how different modes of variability contribute to uncertainty in climate sensitivity estimates.

Even without the influence of natural variability, the climate response to rising greenhouse gases is not uniform in space, and some regions warm more or less than the global average. Climate models provide one tool of characterizing this warming pattern, but their warming patterns can be biased by processes that are imperfectly represented. It is therefore desirable to quantify the warming pattern from observations. However, observational estimates are influenced by natural variability. This project developed statistical methods to estimate the pattern of response to rising greenhouse gases in observations by using pattern recognition methods to identify and remove patterns that are characteristic of natural variability. To test these methods, this work used ensembles of climate models, where the same model is run many times with different realizations of natural variability. The developed methods have been widely disseminated and are in use by many colleagues in the wider climate science community. A key deliverable of this part of the project was an observationally based estimate of the warming pattern in response to historical greenhouse gas and aerosol changes, with an associated quantification of the uncertainty in this estimate. By comparing this estimate to climate models, this work revealed a systematic bias in the pattern of temperature and pressure change simulated by climate models, a bias which means the real world is more likely to exhibit the current La Ni?a conditions than climate model simulations of the recent past and present. The identification of this bias in the pattern of warming is an important step towards correcting this bias in models and improving model-based projections of regional climate change in the coming decades.
